title: nissan ceo carlos ghosn japan double bass case
story: Carlos Ghosn, , accused of financial misconduct, fled from Japan to the Middle East using a  passport.The Brazilian-born exec spent more than  days in custody following his arrest in November  on four charges of falsying financial statements while boss of Nissan-Renault.Mr Ghosn, , had been under house arrest in Tokyo awaiting trial but managed to evade police surveillance.He said he was escaping “injustice and political persecution” claiming the Japanese justice system was “rigged as guilt is presumed, discrimination rampant, and basic human rights are denied”.Lebanese news channel MTV reports that a group of paramilitaries entered the home posing as musicians hired to perform at a dinner party and left with Ghosn hiding inside a box designed to hold a musical instrument.The box is thought to have been a double bass case, typically around ft in long.Mr Ghosn, who spent his childhood in Lebanon which has no extradition treaty with Japan, is believed to have arrived in Beirut from Istanbul.Ghosn has claimed he was escaping “injustice and political persecution”.He said he would no longer be held hostage by a rigged Japanese justice system where guilt is presumed, discrimination is rampant, and basic human rights are denied.Ghosn spent his childhood in Lebanon, where officials have confirmed he entered the country legally.He is believed to have travelled to capital Beirut via Istanbul.Pictures from Beirut show Lebanese internal security forces parked outside a luxurious home identied by court documents as belonging to Ghosn.Lebanon currently has no extradition treaty with Japan.One of his lawyers, Junichiro Hironaka, has called his behaviour “inexcusable”.The episode represents a dramatic fall for Ghosn, hailed for rescuing Nissan, which he led from near bankruptcy over two decades.He was also chairman and chief executive of Nissan’s French partner Renault.

title: uk weather met office hottest december day
story: The Met Office said the peak, brought on by a wave of warm air, was recorded in the hamlet of Achfary on Scotlands north coast on Saturday.It said the reading would have to be quality controlled, butvalidated would be the highest temperatures officially recorded in the UK during December.The average maximum temperature across Scotland during the winter months is five degrees, with higher ground typically seeing dozens of days of snow.The previous record for the highest December temperature was .C, taken in Achnashellach, also in the Highlands, in .The Highlands experience these higher temperature because of a phenomenon known as the Foehn Effect.The effect is produced when strong winds push humid air over high ground, cooling the air as it rises.As the air cools, the moisture in it condenses and forms clouds and rains.The remaining dry air then falls back down the other side of the high ground, gathering heat as it goes and bringing warmer temperatures when it reaches the bottom.The Highlands see the effect when moist westerly winds encounter high ground on Scotlands west coast.As well as the Highlands, the UK also typically sees the effect in the mountainous regions of northeast Wales and northeast England.On Saturday, the northern part of Scotland saw strong southerly winds.In contrast to the .C high, the lowest temperature seen in the UK on Saturday was .C, which was recorded in Writtle, Essex.The December record comes in the same year that Cambridge saw a record July temperature of .C.The effects of global warming have in recent years seen average temperatures rising around the world.In February, NASA said that , , , and  had been the four hottest years on record since .Global temperatures are now .C warmer than the average recorded between  and .

title: sun readers 2020 britain themselves
story: With a strong Tory Government, many can’t wait to “get Brexit done”, as Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised.They are also concerned with our NHS, police, security, global warming and the environment.And they want action on housing and problems on the high street.Here,  readers tell KATE JACKSON of their visions for the year  and beyond . . .DAN ASPLEY, , and we MARIE from Warton, Warks, are parents to -year-old CALLIE who has a rare form of dwarfism called RCDP.Marie, , a sales ledger supervisor, says: “This time last year we were told we might lose Callie because her health was so bad.“But she’s a fighter and after months in hospital we were able to bring her home. Dan was already a full-time carer but in  I had to take six months off work so that we could share -hour care for Callie. We also had to give up our house.“For that reason our vision for  would be for The Sun’s Give It Back campaign to succeed and the Government to fund children’s social care properly.”“I hope it will happen this year, as soon as possible. Perhaps I will adopt some more children.”Fashion accessory seller DEBBIE JECKELLS, , is from Colchester, Essex.She says: “Smaller businesses are struggling these days and I think people should use their local traders rather than the big shop that does everything.“Boris has said he will help smaller businesses and that will be welcomed.“I think things will get tougher for everyone and the economy is a worry.“The environment could be a problem too. If they keep changing the milestones, I am going to be in trouble.”Barista and coffee shop owner OZQIN PORTO, , is from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex.He says: “I want to see people happy and there has to be lots of jobs for young people.“I have many young people in my shop and I want them to be successful.“We need more help for autistic children than what is available at the moment.“Our children are the future and need more help.”EMILY BARTON, , is a charity worker from London.She says: “I wish there was a bit more equality in the world. story: The previously unseen footage was released by the Kremlin to commemorate the th anniversary since the former KGB spy became Russian President.According to Putin’s own press service, the video was filmed in December  at Cuban health resort Varadero.In the clip, the Moscow hardman grabs onto the dolphins’ fins as he is dragged through the water.Vlad, who is known for his love of animals, is then kissed on the face by the adorable sea creatures.But this isnt the first time that Putin has been pictured cavorting with wildle.The bald-headed bruiser has cultivated a rugged strongman persona within his own country meaning he is often pictured shirtless in the Russian countryside.Heres a rundown of the Putins most memorable moments in nature.In  the cult of Putin was born with these remarkable images. title: new decade improve politics
story: But let’s be frank. Things can only improve on the last four years of anger, ision and political paralysis.A period which should have been pivotal to our country saw it barely governed at all. That all changed at pm on December .Boris Johnson’s thumping election win gives us the greatest opportunity for radical renewal since at least .That means finally achieving Brexit  days from now and then, we hope, rapidly ­striking trade deals with Brussels and the world’s greatest economies.It means a dramatic, imaginative ­Budget to turbo-charge both those “left-behind” regions which voted Tory for the first time and the wider economy.We share too the  vision of our readers: For huge NHS investment to continue and a long-term social care solution be put in place.That tax breaks and rate cuts must renew our dilapidated High Streets and help small firms thrive and create jobs.That rough sleeping must be slashed, even ended. That wages must be driven up and food banks rendered redundant.That the Tories must continue striving for a cleaner environment without ­caving in to economy-wrecking panic.And we of course share the desire for a kinder, more united country — echoed by the open letter from faith, ­culture, sport and business leaders.The Sun is optimistic about that too.In fact we do not agree we have suffered a “decade of ision”. Yes, it was tough financially. But we were far from ided at, say, the  Olympics.The anger in our Parliament, offices, factories and homes was caused by Brexit, specically by some Remainers’ refusal to accept defeat, and by a Labour Party engulfed by the hostile hard-left.The Brexit heat is fast dissipating now. Boris’s triumph saw to that. Many Remainers are making their peace with it . . . and even seeing its opportunities.Which leaves but one obstacle to the national healing.No one has done more to ide us than Jeremy Corbyn, his thuggish, often anti-Semitic followers and his obnoxious media apologists.Their relentless hatred and dishonest demonisation of opponents toxied both political discourse and Labour’s election fortunes.Yet none of the contenders to replace Corbyn grasps this reality: They can remain a Twitter-obsessed, Tory-hating clique of middle-class Marxist posers calling each other “comrade” but disconnected from working people.Or be viable, mainstream contenders for Government. But not both.Will they make the right choice  It’s January , , and we live in hope.We are far more sure that Britain, fully independent for the first time in  years, will enjoy a golden decade in the ’s.Happy New Year to you all! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg shift opinions
story: Thanks to the -year-old Swedish climate change campaigner many more of us are eco-warriors these days. Whichever box we ticked in the election, millions of us vote green with our lestyles.A recent survey of Sun readers showed  per cent recognise climate change is real and that  per cent of us worry more about our environmental impact now than they did five years ago.And  per cent of Sun readers want to make their habits greener still.Some of them make their voices heard.Retired receptionist Eileen Webster, , says “climate change is the big issue facing the next generation”, while Anna Lubecka, , demands new PM Boris Johnson, “start making good plans for climate change”.Attitudes to environmentalism have shted so much that being green is now no longer the preserve of lentil-munching hippies and Swampy, it is totally mainstream.No trendy bar would now dare put plastic straws in their cocktails.We’ve all got used to carrying Love Island-style water bottles and happily adopted reusable coffee cups. This year they pulled off a plastic-free Glastonbury, despite a few hiccups.We’ve long stopped grumbling about taking our own bags to the supermarket and got used to stuffing our pockets with them when we leave the house.So now in England, the average person uses less than a tenth of the number of single-use plastic bags than we did five years ago. Only around ten a year, compared to  in .As electric cars have improved, we’ve all been seduced — and not just by Tesla’s new “bulletproof” Cybertruck. Overall, demand for electric cars has jumped, with the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders finding that this November alone electric car sales leaped by . per cent, with more than three times as many new battery-electric vehicles registered as in the same month in .Nowhere  is it clearer that green has become the new black than in fashion, where criticism of fast fashion has led to trends for vintage, second hand and renting rather than buying.On the high street, companies such as HM have launched their “conscious collection” , fashion bible Vogue has championed sustainable designs, while French President Emmanuel Macron’s “fashion pact” — presented at the G summit and intended to make the industry more sustainable — has been signed by more than  brands, including Nike, Zara and Gap.All these changes prove how far we have come and the impact Greta has had.Hearing her, strong and calm, on Radio ’s Today programme this week, what struck me is that now another change is needed.This time a sht not in our actions, but in how we approach the environmental debate.It’s not beliefs but attitudes that need to change. Until now, environmental issues have been too isive.Butwe want real change we’ve got to move beyond blame.It puts people off environmental issues when campaigners hector and shame them.When wealthy celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough criticise normal people for taking holidays with cheap flights, or actress Emma Thompson jets back from America to harass normal people driving to work.In the same way Extinction Rebellion threatens to lose potential supporters when it starts fights with commuters trying to board their morning train or cause mayhem in central London.The real danger is that by being so aggressive, these green campaigners risk putting people off.Greta seems to know this. She is much calmer than she used to be when speaking in public.Rather than getting angry or emotional, instead she has stressed the importance of just, “listening to the scientists”.As usual, we could learn from her.The reality is most people want to be green.We are all concerned about global warming, pollution in the seas and the kind of planet we are creating for our grandkids. But you can’t shame people into doing something.Diesel drivers — especially White Van Man — shouldn’t be harassed just for getting to work. I’m sure they would buy more environmentally friendly vehiclesthey could afford to.Likewise, no one should be shamed for taking a flight — who knows what other measures they might be taking, such as living in a carbon neutral home What the planet needs least is more fighting. Instead we need grown-up debate.The answer to the climate crisis isn’t to criticise each other — it’s to work together to make real change. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leaders call uk heal divided society

title: pope francis lashes worshipper arm st peters square
story: The -year-old was on his way to visit a nativity scene in Vatican Citys central plaza when the woman grabbed his hand and yanked him towards her.He had reached over a barrier to touch a child and had already turned to walk away when he was pulled back.The visibly-shocked pontf stumbled slightly as he moved back towards the barrier and appeared to be in some pain.He then scolded the woman verbally before slapping her hand twice when she still refused to let go.Security guards then moved in to pry the woman off him.The woman had made the sign of the cross as the Pope walked towards her, and was trying to talk to him as she held his hand, although it is not clear what she was saying.After the incident, Francis could be seen walking on looking disgruntled.He was later filmed continuing to shake hands with worshippers and kissing the cheek of a baby passed to his guards by its mother.At the New Years Eve evening service at St Peters Basilica, the Pope told the congregation to practice solidarity and to build bridges, not walls.On Christmas Eve, he said the light of Christmas should be allowed to counter the darkness of human hearts, mentioning in particular unrest in Ukraine, Venezuela, Syria, and a number of countries in Africa.He also called for compassion for migrants forced by conflicts and economic hardship to emigrate in the hope of a secure le.He said that after perilous journeys, they are often find themselves before walls of indference in places where they might have hoped for a dignied le.The New Years incident is not the first time the Pope has rebuffed affection by the faithful.In March, he was filmed repeatedly pulling away his hand as followers made to kiss his ring during a visit to Italys Holy House of Loreto basilica.Vatican spokesman Alessandro Gisotti later explained the footage, saying: The Holy Father told me that the motivation was very simple: hygiene.He wants to avoid the risk of contagion for the people, not for him.

title: 9 fascinating bits secret history
story: News fascinating bits of secret history revealed in New Year declassied documentsDetails of some of the most important historical moments of the s and s have been released by the National Archives under the  year rule - revealing fascinating insights into Margaret Thatcher, John Major and other key figuresShareCommentsByBrian HuttonMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentBen GlazeNicola Bartlett:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsPrime Minister Margaret Thatcher " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMargaret Thatcheraposs fury over Northern Ireland troop deaths, John Majoraposs all encompassing love of cricket and MPs fears over unflattering camera angles. These are just some of the fascinating details revealed this week in official documents from the s and aposs, newly declassied by National Archives in Dublin and London. The files were released under the  year rule -  years in Ireland - which requires secret documents to be declassied after two decades unless there is a good reason not to. UK documents are revealed by the National Archives at Kew unless they would cause damage to the countryaposs image, national security or foreign relations. In the UK, documents are released twice a year in August and January - but theyaposre still playing catch-up with declassications, after the time limit was reduced from  years to  in . Hereaposs a round-up of the most interesting stories that emerged in this yearaposs releases. . Nuclear weapons could be hidden inside a Northern Ireland mountain  Nuclear weapons could be sited at underground facilities inside a mountain in Northern Ireland, Dublin’s most senior intelligence official advised the government. Colonel L Buckley, then Ireland’s Director of Intelligence, was asked for a briefing for Irish Minister of Foreign Affairs Peter Barry on the possibility of nuclear missiles being on the island in November . In a response marked “Confidential”, Buckley complains that he doesn’t have “the monitoring or surveillance systems” to confirm the movements of UK ships, aircraft and support systems. “Suffice to say any such information would be given the highest security classication and only be available to UK or or other military personnel on the strictest ‘need-to-know’ basis at the highest level,” he added.  But he said the harbour at Sydenham in Belfast could accommodate Royal Navy or Nato ships “equipped with nuclear missiles or weapons”. And he said a military base at Benbradagh Mountain,overlooking Dungiven in Co Derry, the second highest mountain in the Sperrins which was used by US forces during the Cold War to communicate with its north Atlantic fleet, could hold nuclear weapons. “Ben Bradaigh NEof Dungiven has underground facilities, which were originally constructed by US forces for the storage of conventional high explosives but were subsequently redesigned and are understood to be suitable for the storage of nuclear weaponsso required,” he wrote.  Margaret Thatcher “grabbed her handbag” and “stormed out” of a meeting with the Belgian prime minister in a row over the extradition of an Irish priest wanted in London over alleged connections to the IRA A senior Tory adviser told an Irish diplomat about the incident by way of contrasting Thatcher’s “quite natural” way with then Irish Taoiseach Charlie Haughey, adding there was “a lot to be played for between them”.  . Thatcher kept wrongly convicted Birmingham Six in jail to dodge scandal The Thatcher government was reluctant to free the Birmingham Six because of pressure from Tory hardliners and concerns it would cause a “scandal”. A Home Office official admitted the fears to Irish diplomats  years ago. The Irish government was leaned on not to pursue their case with the European Court of Human Rights. PM Margaret Thatcher’s government also feared a backlash from the media. Paddy Hill, Gerry Hunter, Johnny Walker, Hugh ­Callaghan, Richard McIlkenny and Billy Power were freed in  for one of the worst miscarriages of justice after being ly convicted in  for the Birmingham pub bombings that killed  people in November .  . Thatcheraposs fury over aposher boysapos killed in Northern Ireland Margaret Thatcher had warned Northern Ireland’s police chief that she would no longer send “her boys over in waves to be killed” in a rancorous row over who was to blame for the slaughter of eight soldiers in an IRA bomb. Sir John Hermon, then chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, was upset by the “neo-colonial connotations” and “World War I overtones” of the Prime Minister’s dressing down, which he took as distancing of herself from the region, newly declassied files disclose. The IRA detonated a massive roadside bomb, containing  pounds of semtex, as an unmarked bus carrying members from the Light Infantry made its way along the A at Ballygawley, Co Tyrone, after midnight on August , . Eight soldiers - all aged between  and  - were killed and another  were injured. They had been making their way from the airport to their base at Omagh. Six months later, Sir John confided in a diplomat about the “panic reaction” from Downing Street in the wake of the attack as well as tensions between the police and the army over whose fault it was for the deadly security lapse.  . Tory who avoided aposblacks and Irishapos feared for apossecurity implicationsapos of allowing Irish MPAn aposunsavouryapos Tory MP who openly admitted avoiding the blacks and Irish in his constituency feared the security implications of allowing Irish politicians into Westminster .Nicholas Budgen, who took over Enoch Powell’s House of Commons seat for Wolverhampton South West, agreed to have lunch with Richard Ryan, a diplomat in the Irish Embassy in London, in March , a report of the meeting marked “confidential” shows. Ryan was trying to bolster support - and stymie opposition - to the nascent British-Irish Inter-Parliamentary Body, made up of politicians in London and Dublin. . Officials feared John Major would have to aposhide behind plantapos as Bill Clinton visited UK  Officials feared the Prime Minister would be forced to hide behind a pot plant to avoid shaking a Sinn Fein leaderaposs hand. Aides were worried about a chance meeting between PM John Major and Sinn Feinaposs Gerry Adams during US President Bill Clintonaposs trip to the UK. The American President visited London and Belfast in November . Stormont aide Robert Crawford issued the alert for potential embarrassment in a memo to Mr Majoraposs private secretary, Edward Oakden. Mr Crawford wrote: Sinn Feinwill almost certainly be invited to the reception. “We cannot see a way of the Prime Minister avoiding Gerry Adams without reverting to the undignied hiding-behind-the-potted plants scenario, which creates almost as valuable a news story as the first handshake.  Ministers were accused of “manipulating” the grieving Dunblane community in the aftermath of the massacre of  children and their teacher. Parents of youngsters gunned down by murderer Thomas Hamilton demanded an urgent clarication from Prime Minister John Major days after the  tragedy, amid fears the Government was about to U-turn on a pledge to help, a newly-released letter reveals. Relatives were angered by reports Scottish Minister Michael Forsyth was abandoning a pledge to offer taxpayersapos money to rebuild the gym where Hamilton slaughtered five and six-year-olds. The PM and Mr Forsyth were among a delegation to visit the Scottish town after the March  attack. Mr Major confirmed to the headteacher that finding Government cash for the project would not be a problem. Gerry McDermott, spokesman for the school board of governors, said the gesture was a source of great comfort to the community, relieving strain from those most closely involved.  John Major skipped seeing Britainaposs only gold medal of the  Olympics because he wanted to watch cricket instead, official records suggest. Aides to the then Prime Minister tried to persuade him to fly to the US to attend the Atlanta Games. Plans included watching the final of the coxless pairs rowing, featuring Matthew Pinsent and Steve Redgrave, which delivered Britainaposs only gold medal at the Games. But cricket fan Mr Major pulled out of a three-night trip to America at the end of July, despite months of organisation behind the scenes, amid concerns from aides he would go to Englandaposs match with Pakistan. Downing Street private secretary Rachael Reynolds wrote to the PM saying: I understand that you are thinking of staying here for the Lordaposs Test in preference to going to the Olympics. “While having to declare certain personal interest here ... I do think it would be a pityyou were to give up going entirely.”  . Heathrow nearly had its name changed to pay tribute to Winston Churchill John Major considered renaming Heathrow Airport after Sir Winston Churchill. The then Prime Minister believed the idea of making Britain’s biggest airport a memorial to the Second World War leader was “intriguing”. The Tory leader asked senior Whitehall aides to explore the proposal after London businessman Harvey Spack suggested Sir Winston Churchill Airport was better than “stupid” Heathrow. The premieraposs reply to Mr Spack said: “Thank you for your letter of  September and for your intriguing idea about renaming Heathrow airport after Sir Winston Churchill. “I am looking into this, and I am grateful to you for raising it.”

title: remain leave chiefs unite call
story: NewsRemain and Leave chiefs unite to call on Britain to come together for Brexit chief Matthew Elliott and Remain boss Will Straw called on the nation to finally begin the healing process as Britain marches into a new decadeShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JAN NewsVote Leave chief Matthew Elliott " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit rivals, civic leaders and religious figureheads today urge Britain to reunite and reconnect as the country marches into a new decade. As the UK prepares to leave the European Union in just  days, the Leave and Remain campaign chiefs call on the nation to finally begin the healing process – a plea echoed by the Archbishop of Canterbury in his New Year message. Three-and-a-half years since voters split by % to % to quit the EU, Matthew Elliott and Will Straw urge Britain to “leave behind a decade of ision and begin our decade of reconnection”. Mr Elliott was chief executive of Vote Leave, the official pro-Brexit campaign, while Mr Straw was his direct counterpart as executive director of Britain Stronger in Europe. They hope factions, friends and families separated by the passionate arguments surrounding the EU debate can now put aside their dferences. The identical demands spanning the political ide are aimed at moving on from the bitter isions which erupted in the run-up to the  referendum and which are yet to be bridged. Their message comes in an open letter signed by a cross-section of society leaders to mark the start of a new decade. Signatories include GMB union chief Tim Roache Confederation of British Industry director Dame Carolyn Fairbairn and Glastonbury Festival organiser Emily Eavis.  Faith chiefs, think tank bosses and British Olympic Association chairman Sir Hugh Robertson have also added their names. The letter says: “As we start this new year and new decade, our country feels more fragmented than any of us would like. “Too often we hear that our isions – by class or geography, by politics, age, race or by faith – have come to define us. “If we are not happy with the state of our society, it falls to us all to do something about it. “New Year is the time for resolutions and on this first day of the s, we urge others to join us in making a resolution for the new decade. “Our resolution is to reconnect. “To reach out to just one person we don’t know, or from whom we have drted apart. “To start rebuilding connections between neighbours and fellow citizens. “While our politics and media have become more polarised we, as people, have not.”Britain is still to recover from the rancour unleashed in the run-up to the landmark referendum.Just a week before polling day, Labour MP Jo Cox was murdered in her West Yorkshire constituency by a far-right extremist shouting: “Britain first!” Experts have blamed the Brexit debate for driving a rise in hate offences ever since.Racist or religious abuse incidents recorded by police in England and Wales jumped % in the month after the UK voted to quit the EU. Some , such crimes were logged in July , rising to , in July , according to the Home Office. Figures revealed in October last year showed an % year-on-year rise in race hate crimes recorded by officers. There were , offences in -, according to Home Office statistics. That compared with , in -, which included the referendum and subsequent months. Charities claimed the figures were the tip of the iceberg because many offences go unreported. The Home Office admitted at the time there had been short-term genuine rises in hate crime following certain events such as the Brexit referendum. In the aftermath of the EU vote, the National Police Chiefsapos Council revealed hate crimes reported to police soared % between polling day and the following Sunday, compared with the equivalent days four weeks earlier. The letter published today is the latest attempt to urge people to “find some common ground”. It goes on: There is much that we share with each other: sit any two people down together and they will find some common ground. “So the power of reconnection will depend on how many of us, as citizens, step up together. “Every institution, too – not just government but education, business, sport, civic society and faith – should play its part in helping bridge social ides. “Today is about a small first step that we can all take – to leave behind a decade of ision and begin our decade of reconnection.”  In his traditional New Year message, the Church of Englandaposs most senior minister, Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, also pleads for chasms to be overcome and the UK to start healing isions. Archbishop Justin says he has been inspired by the heroism and hope of RNLI volunteers at Dover leboat station. In his message, broadcast on BBC at pm today, he says: As we wonder how we are going to start healing some of the isions that weaposve seen over recent years, the sort of people at this leboat station are signs of hope. Iaposve met some of the over  volunteers who are involved in keeping this station operational  hours a day,  days a year. “Itaposs not just a group of people working together, itaposs a family. The seagoing crew includes a student, a train driver, a chef, an electrician. The youngest is , the oldest is . When their pagers go off - day or night - theyaposre prepared to risk everything to rescue whoever needs their help. There are so many ways we can connect with others. “It could be by joining a voluntary organisation or a charity, it may be sorting food in a foodbank or joining a leboat crew. When we hear someone described as a Good Samaritan, we think about that person taking the time to help another. “But itaposs a story told by Jesus about someone taking the risk of reaching out to another who was very dferent to them. “Yes, the person needed help - but they also needed connection.”

title: british woman learns walk again
story: NewsBritish woman learns to walk again after flesh-eating bug nearly killed herDonna Cox, of Rochdale, Greater Manchester was diagnosed with with the flesh-eating bug necrotising fasciitis after getting bitten while travelling in Vietnam, and it resulted in her developing sepsis, which led to her nearly having her leg amputatedShareCommentsByBrendan McFaddenCharlotte Dobson:,  DEC NewsDonna Cox, , booked a one-way ticket to Vietnam in September to celebrate completing her masters degree " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has told how she had to learn to walk again after getting bitten by a mosquito while travelling in Vietnam. Donna Cox, , booked a one-way ticket to Vietnam in September to celebrate completing her degree. But after travelling on to Cambodia she noticed a painful mosquito bite on her right leg. When Donna, of Rochdale, Gloucestershire flew back to the UK, she was diagnosed with the flesh-eating bug necrotising fasciitis.Things got worse when the bug resulted in her developing sepsis which nearly killed her and led to her nearly having her leg amputated, the Manchester Evening News reported .Donna, who had all of the necessary vaccinations before her trip, said: I was having the time of my le. I met some absolutely amazing people. I never expected it all to end as quickly as it did. There was a lump around the bite on my shin. It just didnapost seem right. Iaposd been bitten loads when I was over there. The mosquitoes seemed to love me. But the redness and the pain around this one bite started to spread up and down my leg. Donna went to a pharmacist to get antibiotic cream on the advice of a hostel manager, but a day later the swelling ed and it became too painful for her to put weight on her right foot.  Donna said: I remember saying to some of the girls in the room: aposGuys, Iaposm not being dramatic but I think Iaposm going to die or lose my legapos. I was only joking but it almost ended up coming true. With cash running low, Donna decided to book a flight back to the UK in October. It was a painful flight back and when she made it to Rochdale the bite only got worse. Donna ended up in Rochdale Infirmary AE where an x-ray revealed a aposcollectionapos under her leg, where doctors consulted with the North Manchester Infectious Diseases team. The next day Donna was rushed to The Royal Oldham Hospital where she was diagnosed with necrotising fasciitis. The rare bacterial infection spreads rapidly and can be fatal. Donna started to fall unconscious and developed sepsis, causing her body to start to shut down. The following four days were a blur for Donna. She underwent three operations on her leg and was diagnosed with compartment syndrome. Donna signed a form consenting to her leg being amputated should her condition worsen. Another limb-saving procedure to ease the pressure building in her right leg followed.  Donna said: The bone in my leg had softened and the necrotising fasciitis was eating my leg. It was only because I was young and strong that I survived. There were many traumatising moments for Donna during her time in hospital. Medics left her wound open to ease the pressure in her lower leg, before closing it with  staples. At one stage Donna wore an eye-mask so she didnapost have to look at her leg. Doctors told her thatshe had gone to hospital four hours later she would have died. Donnaaposs illness has changed her le forever, and while she survived, she has lost all sensation in her lower right leg and is now learning how to walk again.

Harry Weir was diagnosed with a chronic kidney disease aged two and has been seriously ill most of his le, with daily dialysis treatment helping keep him alive.But thanks to the heartwarming act by his dad, Mike and the anonymous donor he is now on the road to recovery, Wales Online reports .Mike, from Llantrisant, Glamorgan, Wales, said: We understand that a transplant is not a cure and le will never be normal for Harry or us. However we now have a healthier son and hopes and dreams to live for. Harry was born with ing kidneys but was regularly ill as a baby and toddler and suffered from constipation and viruses. It was only when he was admitted to the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, with a virus that a urine test showed he had issues with his kidneys. At three years old Harry had a biopsy and was diagnosed with FSGS , a chronic kidney condition in both kidneys that would only get worse.Mike said: We dealt with Harryaposs illness for many years. We knew when his kidneys were struggling as he started having headaches and it would then be time to get the sick bowl out as he would have hours of extreme vomiting and eventually fall asleep.This would often happen after heaposd eaten too much or exerted himself. At this point Harryaposs kidneys were ing at % and he was on a lot of medication to try and stem the decline in his kidney . It was when Harry turned five years old that his health signicantly deteriorated and his kidneydropped to just %. He was so poorly that the doctors suggested an intense chemotherapy session as a last chance to save his kidneys. Unfortunately this didnapost work and our little boy was in desperate need of a kidney as his kidneydropped to %. Harry was discharged from hospital but spent two years on dialysis which he would need at home for  hours every night. Mike added: My we and I had to be trained on how to administer the dialysis. It was so noisy and therefore everyoneaposs sleep was disrupted. It was tough on the whole family. My we Karen and I hardly spent any time together. Harry’s older brother Liam had a tough time, bless him, and Iaposll never forget him coming into my bedroom one evening askingHarry was going to die.  As soon as Harryaposs kidneys failed his family were all tested to seethey were a match – and luckily his mum Karen was. But a CT scan showed she had too many arteries in her kidneys which would make the operation too risky. But the family were given a leline when doctors suggested exploring pooled donation involving  Mike and another donor - where two or more pairs of donors and recipients are involved in the swap. Mike said there are around  children in the UK on the kidney transplant list, which meant Harry was on the list for  months without a single phone call. Every quarter, the UK Living Kidney Sharing Schemeassess the donors and recipients to seethere is a match. These operations are coordinated so they are done at the same time. We were all set to go, a week before Christmas, when we found out that our matched recipient wasnapost well enough to proceed, said Mike. We had the choice to wait for another pair or wait for them to get better. We decided to wait it out and within a few months we were ready to go again. Mike admitted that he didnapost really have time to think about undergoing the operation to remove his kidney. My we was at Bristol Children’s hospital with Harry and I was at the Heath in Cardf. I was just so happy to be able to do something to help save Harry. All donations are anonymous and the only information accessible to recipients and donors is the gender, age, and location of their counterpart. Mike said: We wrote a letter to both our donor and my recipient and at the time didnapost know that they were husband and we.

story: NewsDementia-friendly prefab homes coming to UK to help house ageing populationThe concept was the brainchild of the founder of Swedish furniture giant Ikea, Ing Kamprad, before his death and could be the answer to Britain’s dementia crisisShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  DEC NewsThe idea was the brainchild of the founder of Ikea" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDementia-friendly ‘prefab’ apartments could be coming to Britain to house our ageing population. Prefabs - or prefabricated houses - were erected across the UK after the Second World War to tackle the country’s housing shortage. They could now be the answer to Britain’s dementia crisis with numbers of sufferers expected to double in the next two decades. The concept was the brainchild of the founder of Swedish furniture giant Ikea, Ing Kamprad, before his death. Billionaire Mr Kamprad hoped to allow dementia patients and their carers to remain living at home for longer and made a donation to a Swedish dementia charity. The charity approached prefab building firm BoKlok to develop the apartments which have automatic doors and wide entrances to accommodate a wheelchair. They are built around park-like communal gardens for picnics and barbecues. Should one of the residents have dementia diagnosed, the flat can be easily upgraded with a host of special features such as adjustable wash basins, knobs and heat sensors on the ovens, and an alarm button in the bathroom. BoKlok is holding talks with the local authorities in Bristol and Swindon over building its standard prefabs and its dementia-friendly apartments could follow. In Sweden the number of people aged  or over will increase by  per cent from  to ,” Jonas Spangenberg, the chief executive of BoKlok. Society needs to find a solution where more people can stay at home for longer, and actually people want to stay in their own home. This is also much cheaper for everybody. There are currently around , people with dementia in the UK. This is projected to rise to . million by .  Two thirds of the cost of dementia is paid by people with dementia and their families. Unpaid carers supporting someone with dementia save the UK economy £. billion a year. The prefab flats are built in a factory then dropped in to place on a building site for assembly. This meaning they are a quick way to increase appropriate housing stock for the UK’s ageing population.

She slammed the hotel saying: You have made this elderly, sick lady very sad this year.The -year-old, who has diabetes and Parkinsonaposs, told Somerset Live she was the only person in the entire -room hotel all night on Christmas Eve.She also claims she came down to a dark room littered with rubbish from the night before on Christmas morning, with staff unaware that she was booked in or had paid for breakfast. A spokesman for Radstock Hotel has apologised to Mrs Dodd - but says there is a member of staff on site at all times. Mrs Dodd stayed at the Radstock Hotel while she was visiting family in the area but has been upset by the experience. I am lost for words. I just sit and cry, she said. I had planned this super two night break in a hotel for Christmas and it was a nightmare. I would have been better off here in my little flat home alone. Radstock Hotel, you have made this elderly, sick lady very sad this year. Mrs Dodd says she got to the hotel at pm on Christmas Eve. She said: My daughteraposs partner went into the lounge bar to book me in and get my room keys, but it took half an hour before I got them as no one was there except the barman, who was lovely, but he was the only one there serving a pub full of people. Eventually he called someone who let me into my room, but there was no loo roll, and just two milks for my coffee to last for two nights. So, after the Christmas Eve karaoke finished, the downstairs rooms went quiet and I went off to sleep. The grandmother says she got up on Christmas Day morning and ventured downstairs at around am for breakfast. She said: I went in through the lounge bar which was in darkness, and so followed on through to the dining end, which was also in darkness and was absolutely littered with all the junk and rubbish from the night before. So I ambled back through the bar to be met by two young kitchen workers who had just come in and who were shocked to see me standing there. aposBreakfastapos, I asked. They looked at me cockled. They didnapost even know anyone was staying, let alone booked in and paid for breakfast. Apparently I was the only one in the whole building for the whole night alone. aposSo where is the managerapos I asked, aposlives in a cottage around the backapos, they said.  Mrs Dodd added: How scary it was that to think I was in that hotel alone all night and what a brilliant way to start my Christmas day. The boys were brilliant and made me egg on toast. Just so I could take my  medicines that I need to keep me going each day. I am almost , and have had three small strokes, which led to me having Parkinsonaposs. I also have Fibromyalgia and diabetes, yet I was alone in that hotel for the night. After a lovely day with her daughter and grandchildren, the family ed to the hotel at pm.  Mrs Dodd said: They stayed and had a drink, and then we chatted to the bar lady, explaining the night before, and checking what was happening about breakfast in the morning, and she apologised about earlier and said there would definitely be breakfast in the morning and that there were nine other guests staying the night. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenage boy somehow survived after taking drugs laced with rat poison at a concert.OdhranHearty Coburn, , defied a % chance of survival diagnosis when his temperature rocketed to C and he went into multi-organ failure. The teen took a £ MDMA or ecstasy tablet but was unaware it was made up of % rat poison.Now his mum has today told Irish Mirror she feared her son was going to die.But Odi pulled through in hospital and is now back at school part time. Mum Grainne and her husband Alan, from Dundalk, Co Louth, were celebrating a friend’s wedding in London when the call of every parent’s nightmare came through. Just before the first dance, we got a call to say Odi was in the Belfast Mater Hospital in resuscitation and to call them immediately, said the mum-of-three. Seemingly Odi had got himself to a paramedic at the concert and told them he didn’t feel well, that he was a type one diabetic and had taken insulin fteen minutes beforehand. Within three minutes, he started seizing and convulsing. His temperature was  degrees and despite packing him in ice, it remained at  degrees for  hours. We couldn’t get a flight home from London until the next morning so I was in hysterics at the airport all night while Alan was pacing the floors waiting for our hourly updates from the hospital which always told us that Odi wasn’t likely to see the next hour and we probably wouldn’t make it back in time. My -year-old mother Josephine had travelled to the hospital but they wouldn’t let her into intensive care because he was that critically ill.  When they finally reached the hospital the following morning in June, Odi had gone into multi-organ failure. He was hooked up to so many machines which were the only things keeping him alive. He had nothing. No bowels, no kidneys, no liver, no lungs, no heart and no brain. There was no activity. It was our worst nightmare. At the time we didn’t know what had happened but later we found out that Odi had either been given or had taken MDMA at the concert and it took  hours for toxicology to show that it contained % rat poison so our son didn’t stand a hope in hell of making it. Odi was unable to transfer to King’s Hospital in London due to fears he wouldnapost survive the flight. But he was instead brought to St Vincent’s Hospital in Dublin - a centre for excellence for the liver - as medics thoughtthey could just get that vital organ working again, the rest might follow.  Grainne said: There was a vigil for Odi in Dundalk that night and we were watching it on social media. Just as it finished, doctors told us that he was being transferred to Dublin and at that moment, I felt I received my miracle. For  days, Odi was given just a % chance of survival but on the th day, he opened his eyes. He tried to say something and just his expression told me that I had Odi back. I was on bended knee praying for a miracle for months and I received it but as well, God took the backbone of my family instead.” Odi is still going to rehabilitation and is without the use of his left arm and short term memory, which is why he has been unable to tell Grainne what happened at the concert. Sydney put on its famous harbour fireworks show at the stroke of midnight despite calls for it to be cancelled due to Australia’s bushfire crisis, which has claimed more than a dozen lives and ravaged towns. In Auckland, fireworks shot out from the ,ft Sky Tower during a dazzling display watched by tens of thousands of New Yearaposs Eve revellers below. It came an hour after Samoa and Christmas Island in the South Pacic were the first to enter the new year, kicking off celebrations around the world. Click here to follow our live blog for the latest videos, photos and updates from New Yearaposs celebrations around the world. Sydney Harbour was cloaked in smoke on another sweltering day as huge crowds gathered hours in advance to claim a good spot for the display, which annually ranks among the worldaposs best. But more than , people had signed a petition urging Sydney to cancel the celebration due to the wildfires.The city pressed ahead with its plans and was granted an exemption from a total fire ban. She told reporters that much of the event’s budget had already been spent and the event generates almost £million for the New South Wales economy. As the rest of Australia rings in the new year, they will be joined by revellers in Japan and South Korea. Fireworks are also likely in North Koreaaposs capital Pyongyang.  Hong Kong cancelled its fireworks as pro-democracy protesters staged rallies around the city urging people not to give up the fight for democracy in . Demonstrators were encouraged to wear masks at the “Don’t forget  - Persist in ” rally. Police were deploying more than , officers, setting the stage for potential clashes, local media reported.  Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said more than six months of unrest in the financial hub had caused sadness, anxiety, disappointment and rage, adding: “Let’s start  with a new resolution, to restore order and harmony in society. “So we can begin again, together.”  From pm UK time, celebrations will spread from China and Singapore to across Asia and the Middle East, where Dubai promises a dazzling display at pm UK time. Celebrations will then reach Europe as Moscow rings in  with fireworks in the Red Square at pm UK time. The Russian capital has dumped articial snow in the city centre for the celebrations as it experiences its warmest December since .Large fireworks shows are planned across the UK for the stroke of midnight. More than , people will gather along the River Thames to watch Londonaposs sold-out fireworks show. It includes , fireworks, including , that will be fired from the London Eye. Big Benaposs chimes will kick off the display as they sound for the first time in a year amid renovation work. London is hosting Euro  football championship matches, including the final, next summer, and Mayor Sadiq Khan said the capitalaposs role would be celebrated.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pole dancer is suing Russia’s top ski resort claiming a falling pine tree on a piste ended her career. Maria Sirotenko, , suffered  fractures when she was hit on her snowboard at Roza Khutor. She needed three major surgical operations which now allows her to walk again - but she is permanently registered as disabled. Her career as a pole dancer and actress in Novosibirsk is over, according to her legal claim against the popular snow-and-sea resort, venue of the  Winter Olympics. Maria was queueing at a ski lt when a ft pine tree fell on her, trapping the woman. A video shows skiers desperately trying to lt the tree from her. A dozen men failed to budge it and she was only freed after rescuers used chainsaws to cut the trunk. She suffered head injuries, a multiple hip fracture, and five broken vertebrae in her back.  She also had broken ribs and shoulder bones. Maria - who also worked as an eyelash extension artist before the accident - has put on almost two stone in weight since the tree fall changed her le, say reports.  A criminal case has been launched into the case but Komsomolskaya Pravdanewspaper revealed that the ex-pole dancer is also seeking exemplary moral damages from the five-star resort. State prosecutor Olga Pedriko said the claimant wanted £, in medical fees beyond money already paid by the resort for the  accident. But she is also suing for half the fine paid for negligence by the owners of Roza Khutor ski resort, the amount for which is still to be determined.

title: cctv images show the moment customer tackled crook in dundee newsagents
story: Shocking CCTV images show the moment a crook robbed a city newsagents – and police have revealed they are following a positive line of inquiry into the attempted heist.A Dundee shopkeeper has praised a have-a-go-hero customer who tackled a man brandishing a weapon inside the store.Arsalan Haider, Court Street News manager, released images this week of the incident which police are still investigating.Pictures show the customer #hugging# the man after he had reportedly swung wildly at the -year-old shopkeeper in a fit of rage after demanding cash.Police confirmed they are following a #positive line of inquiry# into the incident which took place on Wednesday December .Arsalan said the woman was a regular customer before thanking her today for her actions during the disturbance which took place shortly after pm that day.Describing the incident he said the man had used a metal frame from a chewing gum stand at the front counter before the customer intervened.He added: #If that customer hadn#t have been here it could have got worse # she massively defused the situation by taking the man outside.#I#d pushed the panic alarm during the incident before he fled the scene. It has all been caught on CCTV but the guy was swinging the bulky metal frame at me as he was demanding cash.#The ordeal within the store had gone on for around  minutes before the situation escalated.He added: #I was surprised and thankful that a customer had chosen to intervene in the matter.#The police came and took the CCTV footage from the incident and they knew of the man involved.#Court Street News has been targeted in a spate of incidents in recent years with Arsalan being assaulted during a disturbance in August .He added: #We have taken every measure to try and deter these incidents from happening, with CCTV and panic alarms, but these things continue to happen.#Given the troubles in the past the customers weren#t surprised to hear what has happened here last week.#Thankfully no one was injured but theyare worried because of everything that#s happened in the past that we might close the shop.#A spokesman for the force added: #We are following positive lines of inquiry.#

title: company to expand base in city
story: Dundee-based people development firm Insights is looking to expand its footprint in the city.The company, which operates from two buildings at Dundee Technology Park, counts tech giants Microsoft, Google and Facebook pharma firms GSK and Lilly and BP among its roster of clients.Insights programmes seek to improve self-awareness, leadership, communication and teamwork.After a record year of revenues, group chief executive Andy Lothian said the company was looking at more office space in Dundee.“We want to play our part in re-energising Dundee,” he said.“We are going to continue to create employment in the city and we are looking at a third space in the technology park just now. Long term we are going to find a central solution.“It’s important to us that we invest in Dundee and the people here.”Insights’ sales rose to £. million for the year ending March , an increase from £.m in .Pre-tax profits of £.m were % ahead of last year.Mr Lothian said the results reflected organic growth and the acquisition of a full share in its joint ventures throughout the world.“It’s been an important strategic step for the company buying out our joint venture partners,” he said.“When you are dealing with global clients they want consistency of service throughout the world and that’s helped us to make sure we’re delivering that.”

title: dundee united 1 1 dundee dorrans first goal earns dee derby point
story: Graham Dorrans# first goal for Dundee earned his side a point as they came from behind at Tannadice to end Dundee United#s derby dominance.Nicky Clark had given league leaders United an early advantage but Dorrans rled home the equaliser in the second period to end the Terrors# nine-game winning streak and perfect derby record this season.Dundee were unchanged from their win over Partick last weekend while Louis Appere replaced the injured Sam Stanton for United.And it was the Tangerines who got off to a dream start in front of a , near-sell-out, scoring with the first attack and shot of the game after just five minutes.Appere released Jamie Robson on the overlap down the left and the full-back#s delivery was flicked home by Clark for his seventh goal of the season.Action threatened to boil over on  minutes as Robson and Dundee#s Paul McGowan exchanged handbags in the corner but referee Alan Muir kept his cards in his pocket.And it was McGowan who had the Dark Blues# first real chance of the game on  minutes.The -year-old picked up on a Jordan Marshall cut back, twisted and turned in the box to make some space but saw his shot deflected behind for a corner.On  minutes McGowan was again denied by Siegrist inside the box as he collected a lovely reverse pass from -year-old Fin Robertson but couldn#t find a way past the big Swiss.Terrors talisman Lawrence Shankland had his first clear-cut chance of the game  minutes before half-time but couldn#t head home from six yards out after Robson#s delivery.Calum Butcher escaped a booking on two counts as he went in heavy on Danny Johnson and McGowan as tempers began to flare as the game approached half-time.Dee keeper Jack Hamilton did well to deny Ian Harkes from close range to keep the score down at the interval.Much like the opening period, there was an early goal to start the second half # and it was Dundee who got it.Five minutes after the action restarted Dorrans got on the end of Liam Smith#s clearance to rle home a left-footed volley for his first goal for the club.With the match level, the Dark Blues almost took the lead moments later as Johnson was inches away from getting on the end of a Sean Mackie cross.On  minutes, Shankland went close as he nodded Paul McMullan#s cross just wide of Hamilton#s left-hand post as both teams pushed for a winner.However, both sides had to settle for a point apiece as they go into the new year United sitting top and Dundee in play-off contention.Dundee United XI : SiegristL Smith, Watson, Reynolds , Robson Butcher, Harkes, McMullan, Clark , Appere Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Connolly, C Smith, Chalmers, King and Mochrie.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, McGhee, Meekings , Marshall McGowan, Robertson, Dorrans, Mackie Hemmings, Johnson .Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Todd, Byrne, Moore and Mulligan.Ref: Alan Muir.Att: , .

title: aberdeen slimming group gets chatty with alan carr
story: A group of slimming consultants from Aberdeen celebrated their groups’ successes by meeting a top chat show host and comedian.TV personality Alan Carr co-hosted the annual Slimming World Awards with the organisation’s founder and chair Margaret Miles-Bramwell.The team, which runs Slimming World groups in Aberdeen, were delighted to get a chance to meet Alan. Consultant Colleen Leask saying it was the perfect end to a fantastic year.She said: “The Slimming World members make me burst with pride.“Not only have they seen big changes on the scales, many have improved their health and completely changed their lives too.”Alan, who presented comedy chat show Chatty Man on Channel , said it was great to be invited to the event, held at Birmingham’s International Convention Centre.He said: “I met so many people who had transformed their lives. Every one of them spoke passionately about how they couldn’t have made those changes to eat more healthily and become more active without the support of their consultants and group every week.”

title: plea for safe injecting rooms to get go ahead
story: The boss of an Aberdeen charity that helps people battling addictions says safe injection rooms would bring huge benefits to the city.Dermot Craig, community development manager at Aberdeen In Recovery, believes the facilities can kickstart people’s journeys towards getting clean.The Scottish Government wants to introduce the rooms but needs the approval of the UK Government.Under current legislation, the sites, which aim to prevent drug-related deaths and reduce HIV infection, would be illegal and people using them would face being arrested. But they have been deemed a success in countries such as Denmark.Dermot believes the facilities can keep people safe as well as providing an opportunity for support.He said: “I think it would be a measure, especially in harm reduction, that would be very beneficial.“It would have huge benefits and would be a very important addition to the services that already exist.“An awful lot of the problems with substance use is the environment people are injecting in.“If there was a clean environment where people could access help and clean equipment it would mean they were using as safely as possible.“There is also a little window of opportunity where conversations can be started. It could set people on the road to recovery.”Aberdeen North MP Kirsty Blackman said: “Charities like Aberdeen In Recovery and Drugs Action have an immense amount of experience and expertise in supporting iniduals.“I believe all policy makers should recognise and respect that rather than simply reacting with a kneejerk rejection of their position.”A spokeswoman for the Home Office said: “The Government has no plans to introduce drug consumption rooms in the UK.“Illegal drugs devastate lives and communities and those who sell drugs should fear the full consequences of the law.“We are concerned about the rate of drug deaths in Scotland and will continue to work together with the Scottish Government to tackle the problem of drug misuse and drug-related harm.”

title: poundland submits plans aberdeen shopping centre store
story: A discount retailer is making plans to open in a former book shop on the city’s Union Street, The Evening Express can reveal.Poundland has applied for a building warrant from Aberdeen City Council to spend around £, on an internal fit-out of the former Waterstones retail store in the Trinity Centre.The prime city centre site has been lying vacant since the national bookseller moved from the store in May .Dustin Macdonald, chairman of the City Centre Community Council, said he was pleased to see the large unit occupied again.He said: “It’s good to see there’s still interest in Union Street property.“That shop has sat empty for a while and filling such a big unit can’t have been easy.”However, councillor Bill Cormie, who represents Rosemount, said: “We need to watch that Union Street doesn’t become a long mall of bookies and discount retailers.”The works would also include the installation of new stairs at ground to first floor level.Waterstones signed a -year lease in  for a two-storey unit in the Bon Accord Centre, Aberdeen.The Trinity Centre branch of the bookstore, which had long been a feature of Union Street, was previously occupied by another book store, Ottakar’s.Speaking at the time, bookshop manager Iain Dench said the Bon Accord Centre plan offered an “exciting prospect” for the business.Poundland has a store at  Union Street but it is not known whether this will be affected by the plan.The retailer also has shops in Berryden Retail Park, Inverurie and Elgin.The Trinity Centre and Poundland could not be reached for comment.

title: time to stop stigma surrounding poverty says abernecessities
story: The boss of a north-east charity which helps families tackle poverty wants to break the stigma surrounding the issue.Michelle Herd, chief operating officer of AberNecessities, believes families are worried about the reactions they receive when people find out they are struggling.But she insisted the response the charity has had from the public in Aberdeen shows people are keen to support those in need.The charity posted a video earlier this year featuring the story of a young mum.💔 I’m lost for words 💔 Thank you as always for your support, kindness and encouragement. Please keep it going.. 💜#nochildshouldgowithoutPosted by AberNecessities on Wednesday,  November It was watched more than , times and saw the organisation inundated with messages of support and offers of help.Michelle said: “There is stigma about single parents or people who are on benefits but the mum in our video was overwhelmed with the positive response. We got nothing but positive messages from people asking ‘how can we help’ or ‘how can we make things better for this family’.“People just want to do whatever they can and I think the opportunity is there.“It’s not just about giving a monetary donation.“People can give nearly-new clothes and equipment they have grown out of.“It’s heartbreaking reading the stories. There are a lot of dficult stories and we just hope the items the families get help them.”The charity receives donations of items such as nappies, clothes and bedding, and gives them to families through intermediaries including social workers and schools.Michelle revealed the community in the north-east has helped a huge number of families – estimated to be around  – in the last nine months.She said: “We had a family who only had one lightbulb in the house. If we get an inidual case like that where it’s a simple thing for us to do we will do it.“We had a story recently where a family received a double buggy. They got in touch to say it had changed their lives because they were able to do things like going to the park and going shopping.“Usually it’s all the bad side of things you hear about and how negative people are to others but that’s not the case. There is a huge community spirit in Aberdeen.“That has been going on since we started up in March and we are seeing that continuing.It’s not just this time of year. It’s going on all the time and that’s really heartwarming.”

title: thank god we had niall to give us some quality says mcinnes
story: Boss Derek McInnes today praised Niall McGinn for battling through injury to net an equaliser at Tynecastle.McInnes confirmed the winger had been struggling with a muscle problem and only passed a late fitness test on the morning of the Premiership clash at Hearts.Pittodrie physios deemed the Northern Ireland winger was not fit enough to play for an entire  minutes.McInnes opted to name McGinn on the bench in the hope he could be introduced as an impact substitute.McGinn was brought on late in the first half as a replacement for Zak Vyner.On-loan Bristol City defender Vyner suffered a shoulder injury.Vyner will be assessed by a specialist and McInnes fears surgery may be required which could end the -year-old’s season.McGinn salvaged a - draw for the Reds against the Premiership’s bottom side with a superb free-kick.McInnes said: “Niall has been struggling with injury for the last few weeks.“He has had a little calf, hamstring thing.“It is a nerve thing that has affected his training.“Niall passed a fitness test on the day of the game but the phyisos said he didn’t have  minutes in him. He played  minutes against Livingstonwhen we only planned to play Niall for  minutes.“Niall did not have  minutes in him against Hearts but thank God we had him to call upon.“He has been doing that for years for us now, turning up when the game is screaming for a bit of quality. When we were screaming out for that quality, calmness and decision making Niall was there, as he normally is.”McGinn’s superb -yard free kick came immediately after Hearts had been reduced to  men.Sean Clare received a straight red for pulling back Jon Gallagher as the on-loan Atlanta United attacker broke in on goal.McGinn’s equaliser was the only moment of real attacking quality from Aberdeen. McInnes started with two strikers, Bruce Anderson and Curtis Main.McInnes said: “At half time we spoke with a bit of honesty about how we were not passing the ball well enough or showing enough of ourselves.“We were better when we went back to a more familiar shape with one up when Bruce went up on his own.“In the last  minutes of the game we were devoid of quality, calmness and the right decision making.“We all became a bit too rushed in what we were doing in sailing it forward and not moving the ball quick enough at times.“It was in these moments that we had to show a bit more experience, control and composure to get to their goal and get a winner.“Unfortunately we didn’t do enough to do that.”

title: 39-year-old-knocked-partners-windows-three-hours
story: A -year-old man was thrown out of his partners home but repeatedly knocked on the door and windows for three hours before police were called.Blair Scott pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the domestic-related offence at a house in Kenilworth Avenue, Galashiels, on November .Kate Irwin, prosecuting, said: "The couple had been in a relationship for about a year. The complainer asked him to leave because she believed he had been involved in drugs."He went away but ed at .pm and was repeatedly striking the windows and doors wanting to get back in."This happened for the next three hours before the complainer eventually phoned the police."Sentence was deferred on Scott - now residing in Edinburgh - until January  to establishthere was any reason why a Non-Harassment Order should not be imposed in this case.

title: film-festival-launches-inaugural-photography-competition
story: THE forthcoming Peebles Outdoor Film Festival has launched its first-ever photography competition.And the winners wont just have the chance to win fabulous prizes but also have their work viewed by thousands of people over the festival weekend and beyond.Photographers of all ages are invited to submit images based on the theme of wildness.The deliberately-broad theme can cover a specic place, person, outdoor activity, wildle, landscape, or even just an expression, or feeling.Festival director Rich Rowe said: "It doesnrsquot matterthe images are taken on the fanciest of cameras, or a smartphone, what matters most is that the images tell a story and really stop us in our tracks.An independent  of judges will shortlist a dozen stand-out images that will then be mounted and displayed in the Eastgate Theatrersquos Anne Younger Studio for two weeks, including over the festival weekend.From the dozen images shortlisted, one photograph will be chosen as the winner of the grand prize.The winning photographer will receive a dayrsquos guided photo tour of the Tweed Valley in the expert company of Ian Linton ndash an outstanding local photographer who knows all the best shooting spots ndash plus one nightrsquos bed and breakfast stay at the award-winning Glede Knowe Guest House, Innerleithen.The grand prize winner will be announced ahead of the final film speaker session on Sunday, January .All other shortlisted photographers will receive a pair of tickets to a festival session of their choice.The  Peebles Outdoor Film Festival will be held over the weekend of January -to-.Entry to the festival photography competition costs pound, with photographers able to submit up to five images.Deadline for entries is Friday, January .For entry forms and full details contact e. press@eastgatearts

title: room-inn-sandys-tontine-triumph
story: A PEEBLES historian has gone upmarket in her quest to discover the Royal Burghs past.Sandy Whitnell has previously researched and documented the depravity suffered in the town at the Peebles Poorhouse.From the late s the Combination Poorhouse on Rosetta Road was home to many down-on-their-luck locals.In a bid to find some balance, Sandy went from rags to riches with her next project - and has now charted the history of the glamorous Tontine Hotel.From her initial , word essay for a local history meeting, she decided to investigate the High Street hostelry even further.And this month The Public Rooms of the County has been published.The -page booklet provides readers with a remarkable journey from the hotels grand opening in  all the way through to its popular place on todays High Street.Sandy told us: "It was after Id done my talk on the Peebles poorhouse that I wanted to go to the other extreme and see where the wealthy were staying at the time."It seemed such a shame that the history of The Tontine Hotel hadnt been done before, so I initially wrote up , words."That was just the start."There were three prominent figures involved in the creation of the Tontine Hotel - local MP Sir John Montgomery, banker John Hay, and army captain Robert Nutler Campbell.Their aspirations for a prominent high-class hotel in Peebles led to  people purchasing shares to fund the project.Tontine, named after Italian economist Tonti, derives from the type of investment plan used.The Tontine was built at a cost of pound, - around pound, in todays money - and the doors were opened in .From its early days The Tontine was a popular meeting place for many organisations and societies in and around Peebles.It was also a busy destination for travellers arriving by coach and horse, with its stables being well used, in the days before the railway reached the town.And it wasnt just horses who were stabled at the Tontine, with reports from  of an elephant from Battys Travelling Menagerie dying while being kept at the Tontine.The Public Rooms of the County highlights the grandeur offered with the magnicent ballroom regarded as its crowning glory.Sandays enjoyable book also introduces readers to the vast array of characters who managed the hotel - from Frenchman Benoit Lenoir at the height of the Napoleonic wars and entrepreneurial James Cameron to the bullish Thomas Noble and heroic Duncan McPherson - until its sale into private ownership in the s.The purchase by William Borthwick and Duncan McPherson ended the Tontine arrangement, but the premises kept the name.Although the hotel was sold to a national chain in , it ed to private ownership more recently with the current proprietors Kate and Gordon Innes.Author Sandy admits she struck gold during her research with an enquiry at the National Records office in Edinburgh.She added: "The officer at the National Records produced three unopened boxes full of original documents relating to the hotel."It was an absolute treasure trove for any historian and has helped me produce a very detailed history of this much-loved hotel."The Public Rooms of the County, priced at pound, is available from The Tontine Hotel as well as Amazon.All profits from the sale of The Public Rooms of the County will be shared between the Peebles Foodbank and the Peebles Community Talking Books project.

title: happiness-borders-comes-dalai-lamas-blessing
story: THE Dalai Lama has given his blessing to a new course being run in the Borders which promises to make people happier and the world a better place.The eight-week course is designed by the Action for Happiness organisation - a UK based movement with over , members which takes action for a happier world.Entitled Exploring What Matters, the weekly courses will be offered in Peebles and Innerleithen in the New Year.It is a secular project based on science rather than faith and is open to people of all backgrounds.The course is backed by the Dalai Lama, who said: ldquoAs patron of Action for Happiness I am delighted to see the work being done by members of this movement to create a happier and more caring society."I wholeheartedly support the Exploring What Matters course and hope that many thousands of people will benefit from it and be inspired to take their own action to help create a happier world.Analysis of the course has found that it leaves people both happier and more pro-social, with participants reporting increases in levels of le satisfaction, mental wellbeing, compassion and social trust.Many say the course is le-changing.In Exploring What Matters, local groups meet for eight weeks, with each session exploring a big question.They start with "What really matters in le " and then "What really makes us happy ".These are followed by sessions on dealing with adversity, having good relationships, caring for others, and creating happier workplaces and communities.They end with "How can we create a happier world The first eight week course is being run in Peebles on a voluntary basis by Suzi Gibson and Laura Swan in Space, Greenside every Thursday starting on January .Suzi said: ldquoIrsquom very excited to be running this course because happier iniduals make for a happier community and I am passionate about bringing people together to discuss what matters. I canrsquot think of a better use of my time than helping myself and others be happier.The Innerleithen-based course is being run by Lois Hindley and Cath Shepheard and takes place at Innerleithen Church of Scotland every Wednesday starting on January .And whatrsquos even better is the cost of happiness is free, but the organisers do ask for a small donation to cover costs.If you would like to search for happiness contact Laura Swan at hello@lauraswan
