title: eleanor-nears-100k-target-fundraising-coffee-morning
story: AN -year-old Borders woman has raised more than pound, for a cancer charity.Eleanor Moffat began fundraising following the death of her younger sister through breast cancer.And her latest coffee morning last month in her hometown of Coldstream boosted her personal fundraising tally by another pound.Eleanor, who hopes to raise an incredible pound, for Breast Cancer Now, regularly hosts coffee mornings, charity dinners and bingo nights.She said: "Itrsquos wonderful that so many people came to my coffee morning in support of Breast Cancer Now.ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted to have raised over pound from the event, brining me even closer to my goal of reaching pound, for a cause that is so close to my heart."Thank you to everyone who continues to give so generously.Since Eleanor began fundraising for Breast Cancer Now in  she has raised pound,..Kirsty Potter, fundraising manager at Breast Cancer Now, added: "Breast cancer is the most common cancer in the UK ndash around , people are diagnosed with breast cancer and around , people die from the disease each year in Scotland."We must act now to make greater progress for everyone affected by this disease.ldquoWe are very grateful to every one of our amazing community fundraisers who help us to fund vital breast cancer research and support."We are delighted that Eleanorrsquos coffee morning was a big success and on behalf of Breast Cancer Now I would like to sincerely thank Eleanor and the local community in Coldstream for continuing to support our work, which provides support for today and hope for the future for everyone affected by breast cancer.

title: 7k-boost-philiphaugh-community-schools-new-book-club
story: A PRIMARY school library in Selkirk has received a major boost from the government to create its own book club.Philiphaugh Community School has been awarded more than pound, to help encourage both pupils and parents to .The School Library Improvement Fund supports activities which meet key education priorities, including literacy development, information and digital learning and health and wellbeing.And all of the pound, grant will be used to develop its Brilliant Book Clubs ndash Happy Readers.A total of  school library projects across Scotland have received a combined total of pound, in this round of funding.Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: "School libraries have a vital part to play in supporting literacy and improving attainment right across the curriculum.ldquoWe want libraries to be the vibrant hub of our schools and further investment of pound, through the School Library Improvement Fund will strengthen their role.ldquoI am very pleased to see recipients focussing on not only literacy but health and wellbeing, STEM, and digital learning and engagement with their wider community.A new funding round is set to open for applications on January , with pound, available for creative projects to enhance school library provision.

title: play-part-preserving-scotts-legacy
story: LOOKING for a new activity to enjoy in the New Year Wanting to meet new people or learn something dferent in  Then why not consider a volunteering role at Abbotsford, the home of Sir Walter Scott.The Abbotsford Trust is looking for enthusiastic volunteers of all ages to get involved in the preservation of Scottrsquos legacy and welcoming visitors to his lsquoconundrum castlersquo, gardens and woodlands.A Volunteer Open Day is being held at Abbotsford on Saturday, January , starting at am, form people to learn more about the dferent roles and to sign upthey are interested.Annabel Crawford, Abbotsfordrsquos Volunteer Coordinator, told us: ldquoSir Walter Scottrsquos Abbotsford is one of the most famous literary houses in the world."Looking after this five-star tourist attraction is a major challenge for a small charity and volunteers are absolutely crucial to Abbotsfordrsquos success.ldquoThis year we have a wide range of roles to fill, from selling tickets and helping in the shop, to welcoming visitors to the historic house, driving the minibus and helping with our family events.ldquoNo previous experience is necessary and people can do as many hours as they like."Some of our volunteers do a couple of days a week, while others just do a couple of hours. It all helps us to preserve Scottrsquos legacy for future generations.In  Abbotsford became the first historic house museum in Scotland to gain a prestigious national award for its volunteer programme when it received the Volunteer Friendly Award, a nationalscheme for organisations working with volunteers.Anyone interested in volunteering can call   or email volunteering@scottsabbotsford for more information and to register their interest.Alternatively, they can attend Abbotsford at am on the Saturday th January.

title: historic-galashiels-hotel-celebrates-150-years
story: IT is widely recognised as one of the most spectacular buildings in the Scottish Borders and it has just celebrated its th birthday.Starting le in  as a residential home so Adam Lees Cochrane could keep a watchful eye on the hill overlooking his Netherdale textile mill on the eastern outskirts of Galashiels, it is now better known as the Kingsknowes Hotel.The sesquicentennial anniversary is a notable feat in the history of the hotel trade in Galashiels considering famous establishments such as the Abbotsford, Douglas, Kings, Maxwell, Royal and the Woodlands are now a distant memory.General manager Robert Lamont - a graduate of EHL University in Switzerland which is regarded as the best hospitality school in the world - admits the current climate is not without its challenges particularly with a Premier Inn scheduled to arrive in Tweedbank.But he believes that a business plan is in place so that the Kingsknowes Hotel will continue to thrive for a long time to come.He said: "For a building that it  years old it is in first class condition which is something we are very proud of."There have been major refurbishments in recent years, most particularly the Courtyard Bar, and it is an ongoing programme with more improvements planned in the New Year."A downside has been the loss of the fishing trade with the lack of salmon in the River Tweed, but we have learned to ersy and we are in a good position to keep progressing."We focus strongly on the local community and our repeat trade is excellent for things like bar meals for which we are very grateful."Our head chef Jack Jackson and his team do a great job continually up-dating the menu and it is good to see all the familiar faces regularly coming back."The opening of the Borders Crematorium was a major boost to the business because of our location and the car park and weddings continue to be popular because of the beautul grounds."William Hay designed the red sandstone baronial mansion back in  - now A-Listed along with the conservatory by Historic Scotland - and it has remained largely unaltered over the past  years, apart from being converted into a -bedroom hotel in the s.The Lamont family purchased the Kingknowes Hotel from the Scott family  years ago and the business employs more than  people.

title: pupils-earn-pass-marks-eco-friendly-reindeer-dust
story: PUPILS from across the Borders have been brushing up on eco-friendly reindeer dust in the run up to Christmas.For centuries children have been luring Rudolph, Blitzen, Comet and co with a sprinkling of reindeer dust on Christmas Eve.But some of the ingredients in many of the store-bought dust includes environmentally-damaging glitter as well as grains grown overseas.And at a time of heightened awareness about our planets future, the Royal Highland Education Trust has been enlightening the next generation on producing their own environmentally-friendly reindeer dust.Over the past few weeks officers from the RHET have visited  dferent classes and helped  children produce their own reindeer food.Lesley Mason, RHET Project Coordinator in the Scottish Borders, told us: "All the ingredients in the food are environmentally friendly and will do no harm to the local wildleSantarsquos reindeer donrsquot manage to eat it all."Sessions were delivered in the classroom and provided an opportunity for pupils to try some healthy food, teach them how to make environmentally conscious choices around food and was an overall fun and interactive lesson."For younger nursery students, there was a magic Christmas-themed activity as well."Making reindeer dust with kids was a magical way to encourage interest in farming, food production and environmental issues."I really hope to be able to offer kits to all nurseries and primary schools in Scottish Borders next year.Sponsorship for the eco-friendly dust workshops came from Hamlyns Oats, Booker Cash  Carry and Tesco, Galashiels.The reindeer dust contains porridge oats, Timothy chaff , popcorn and several other secret ingredients.Lesley added: "The projectrsquos aim was to teach pupils how farmers grow food for us and other animals, how food grown locally is better for you and the planet and how eating the right food can make you strong and healthy."Each pack of food contains three pieces of popcorn, as popcorn is the fuel that makes reindeer fly, although too much and the reindeer might never land again."

title: selkirk-fiddle-groups-benefits-eilidhs-trust
story: A SELKIRK-based fiddle group has been awarded funding from a Trust in memory of a Scottish girl killed in the Manchester Arena terrorist attack.Eilidh MacLeod from Barra was one of the  people killed at the Ariana Grande concert in .The -year-old had been passionate about traditional music and played bagpipes with the Sgoil Lionacleit Pipe Band.A charitable trust was set up in Eilidhs memory with proceeds going towards youth music projects across the country.This week a total of pound, was awarded to  groups in the inaugural round of funding from the Eilidh MacLeod Memorial Trust.And included in the beneficiaries is Selkirks Riddell Fiddles who will receive pound.Annag MacLean, trustee of Eilidhrsquos Trust and former headteacher of Barrarsquos Castlebay Community School, told us: ldquoWe are delighted and thrilled to announce the first full funding round of grants for local community music groups across Scotland."This support will contribute to the excellent work they are doing to encourage and nurture the local talent among young musicians and will allow them to continue developing their skills.ldquoThese grants are a demonstration of our commitment and intent to support young musicians in their ambitions in Eilidhrsquos memory."This financial support could only be made possible through the huge generosity of the many people who have donated to our fundraising efforts and the organisations who have supported our work.As well as supporting music education for young people, to reflect Eilidhrsquos own musical ability and enjoyment as a piper, the trust also manages and maintains a permanent memorial to Eilidh and a garden of remembrance and reflection on Barra.It is hoped that a further round of funding will be made in the first half of .Any groups that wish to be considered for support should contact Eilidhrsquos Trust at hello@eilidhstrust.org.uk

title: rileys-christmas-spirit-send-teejay-back-blackpool
story: THE spirit of Christmas came to Galashiels early after an -year-old boy overheard his mum and granny.Riley Higgins was so moved by the plight of five-year-old Teejay Shaw that he wanted to help.Ever since being diagnosed with rare Perthes disease last August, Teejay has undergone operations and hospital stays.The painful childrens condition, which can last for several years, affects the groin, hips and thighs.Teejay was on holiday in Blackpool during August  when he became unwell and was later diagnosed with the condition at the towns Victoria Hospital.When Riley heard how Teejay had to spend his seaside holiday in hospital he, with help from mum Kim, set up a fundraising page in a bid to send the youngster back to Blackpool with his family for another deserved break.And he is now closing in on his pound target.Teejays mum Selena told us: "Myself and TeeJay were very touched to hear that Riley had decided to set up a fundraiser."For an -year-old boy to think of another child is amazing."Rileyrsquos family should be very proud of the kind and caring young man he is. "At an appointment at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh in January, a consultant revealed that TeeJays condition had reached its worst stage and he would require a femoral osteotomy to realign the joints in his hips.But during the procedure TeeJays femur broke.After having a plate and pins inserted into his leg, he was unable to walk for nine weeks.Earlier this month the plate and pins were finally removed.And now he is looking forward to ing to Blackpool next year - without any visits to the hospital.Selena added: "Wersquod like to say a massive thank you to Riley and his family for doing this for TeeJay, thank you to everyone who has shared Rileyrsquos go fund me page and a massive thank you to everyone who has donated online or given cash donations."Perthes Disease affects only one in  children with no clear reason why it occurs.Rileys fundraising page has so far raised around pound.You can donate to the TeeJays Travels crowdfunding page at https:www.gofundme f tee-jays-travels

title: lidl-ban-alleged-hawick-shoplifter
story: A HAWICK man has been banned from the local branch of Lidl until the outcome of his trial.Ioan Dorel, , appeared from custody and pleaded not guilty to a shoplting charge at the shop at the weekend.A trial date has been fixed for March  at Jedburgh Sherf Court with an intermediate hearing on February .

title: no-room-bin-christmas
story: RECYCLING bosses will attempt to empty their bins in Selkirk before the bells.With the towns recycling centre due to close for several days over Christmas and New Year, Souters are left with only three options for dropping off their bottles.But the recycling banks at Sainsburys car park and the Police Station car park are both close to capacity - and the Rugby Club car park is already overflowing.One angry resident told us: "Christmas and New Year are the busiest times for people buying and depositing bottles.This isnt encouraging people to recycle."Surely, the bottle banks should be emptied regularly - the ones at the rugby club have been full since the summer."When the Bordercontacted Scottish Borders Council this week, officers confirmed they would try to organise a collection as soon as was possible.And they are encouraging everyone to use the alternative sites until the uplt is completed.A spokesman said: "We will follow up the report of full bottle banks at Philiphaugh car park in Selkirk.ldquoThere are four locations with bottle banks in Selkirk including Sainsburys car park, the car park alongside the townrsquos police station and within the community recycling centre on Riverside Road.ldquoWe would encourage the public to continue to help the environment by using bottle banks to recycle their glass over the festive period."

title: inspirational-borders-family-launch-legacy-project-scottish-parliament
story: AN Earlston family who have campaigned and fundraised tirelessly since the death of their baby boy have launched a legacy project at the Scottish Parliament.Marie and Keith Briggs have raised over pound, to fund the memory-making project, Joersquos Toes, in conjunction with CHAS for parents who are dealing with the loss of a child.The couple welcomed identical twin boys to the world, eight weeks early in February .Tommy was born shortly after Joe, who was sadly stillborn as a result of twin to twin transfusion syndrome.Tommy spent five weeks in hospital and was cared for both in Special Care Baby Unit in Borders General Hospital and Simpsons Neonatal Intensive Care Unitat the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh.Driven to help fellow families coping with similar loss, Marie and Keith collaborated with CHAS on a memory making project in memory of Joe.In recognition of their endeavour, the family won Tommyrsquos lsquoInspirational Family of the Yearrsquo in the summer.Ahead of their last fundraiser of the year - Dalkeith Country Parkrsquos Santa Run - Marie and Keith joined representatives of CHAS to officially launch the legacy project.Marie said: ldquo has been a fantastic first year for Joersquos Toes and we cannot thank everyone enough for their generosity."This year we have seen everything from a  mile challenge to a head shave, from multiple half marathons to bingo bonanzas."We are astounded by the support shown to us by our local community and further afield.ldquoWe hope everyone knows the dference this will make to bereaved and soon to bereaved parents in their darkest hours."Every donation makes all the dference in helping provide this service to a family in need.ldquoThank you everyone for your kindness. We wish you a very merry Christmas and a prosperous new year!The funds raised for Joersquos Toes allows CHAS to purchase the materials required to make baby hand and foot-casts, as well as special boxes to house them in, respectfully done in Joersquos name.This type of memory making has generally been offered by CHAS within the Hospice, however taking it into the Neonatal Unit is pioneering work, providing another opportunity for parents to make precious lasting memories following the death of their baby.Sarah Dannfald, community fundraiser for CHAS, said: ldquoWe are so thankful to the Briggs family for all their fundraising efforts for CHAS, to help us provide even more families with those precious special memories that will stay with them forever.ldquoMarie and Keith have inspired so many of their friends, family and neighbours to join them and to date they have raised over pound, in memory of Joe."For that we are so grateful and will allow us to provide over  families with the opportunity to make D casts of their childrsquos hand or foot, and display it beautully in the Joersquos Toes Box.During , the Briggs familyrsquos fundraising group has tackled the Tour de Lauder -mile cycling challenge, the Edinburgh half marathon, Gateshead k with the Great North Run, Loch Ness Marathon and many more physically arduous events.They have so far raised an astounding pound,, more than trebling the initial pound, target they set themselves.Anyone wishing to sponsor the project can do so via their Everyday Hero page at https:give.everydayhero uk joe-s-toes

title: marvellous-milestone-golden-eagles-return-borders
story: A FLIGHT of fancy to save golden eagles in the south of Scotland has swooped past a major milestone after just two years.Persecution of the iconic birds as well as changes in land use had led to numbers dropping across the Borders and Dumfries and Galloway in recent decades.Ahead of the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project being launched almost two years ago it was believed that there were only two-to-four breeding pairs left across the whole area.Conservationists had identied enough habitat spread across the two rural local authority regions to comfortably cater for as many as  birds.Eaglets were taken from nests in the north of Scotland by ornithologists to prepare for release in the south.In early  five custom built aviaries were constructed in the Southern Upland hills to allow the first of the eaglets to become accustomed to the new territory.While the work of bringing a new generation of golden eagles to the Borders continued, outreach officers staged school and community visits to provide education on the endangered species.This month, with four eagles now successfully introduced to the south of Scotland, bosses at the project revealed that , people have now supported their work by either volunteering or taking part in the outreach sessions.Philip Munro, community outreach officer for the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Project, told us: ldquoIt is fantastic to see so many people are so passionate about protecting this iconic species in the south of Scotland."We are absolutely delighted with the support, which plays an absolutely vital role in protecting golden eagles."We need to keep building on this so that we can ensure that we can see even more of these magnicent birds across the south of Scotlandrsquos skies for generations to come.Funded by Heritage Lottery and LEADER Scottish Borders and DG, the project aims to bring together all countryside users to ensure the wellbeing and successful future of the eagles in the south of Scotland and to secure its place for the future.Those who have participated in the initiative, ranging from four-years-old up to , come from a range of backgrounds and organisations, including the UKrsquos first ever Golden Eagle Scout Champions at the Scottish Borders Scouts, over  pupils from primary schools across the south of Scotland and one in the Scottish Highlands, Borders College, the Scottish Raptor Study Group, Kielder Bird of Prey Centre, HMP Dumfries, and local businesses like Wild Tree Adventures.Earlier this year, the Philiphaugh Estate near Selkirk also announced that it plans to open a Golden Eagle Centre which will support the projectrsquos conservation and community engagement work.Francesca Osowska, Scottish Natural Heritagersquos chief executive, said: ldquoThis is a fantastic milestone."Golden eagles are such an amazing part of Scotlandrsquos bioersity, and an integral part of building a nature-rich country for us all."Wersquore passionate about ing golden eagles to places where they used to be plentul ndash and it looks like we have thousands of people on our side!"A huge thank you to all the wonderful volunteers and project participants.The first four birds which were moved to the area have settled into their new habitats and are now fending for themselves.Support from volunteers and participants plays a pivotal role in helping the iconic species continue to grow and thrive in the area.One volunteer was shortlisted as Student of the Year by the Scottish Rural College, largely for her work on the project.Charlotte Martin, a Countryside Management student at SRUC, first heard about the Project when Philip Munro delivered a talk at the college.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in areas where golden eagles were part of the fabric of the area and very much accepted and admired, alongside my career in farming with employers who farmed commercially yet with great respect for wildle, I was very excited by the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Projectrsquos aims."I badgered the project team to let me volunteer and have since been helping at public engagement events, which I thoroughly enjoy.As well as colleges, the outreach team have also visited many schools across the Borders.Michelle Hoppeacute, principal teacher for Yarrow  Kirkhope Primary Schools, said: ldquoWe were really excited to be one of the first schools to take part in the South of Scotland Golden Eagle Projectrsquos Eagle Schools initiative."It really brought our community together and I would thoroughly recommend it to anyone."The children have had the most amazing experience."We are incredibly proud of the interest our pupils have shown in protecting this majestic and important bird. We look forward to supporting the project to make sure that Golden Eagles flourish in the south of Scotland.Project partners include RSPB Scotland, Scottish Land  Estates, Scottish Forestry, Scottish Natural Heritage, and the Southern Uplands Partnership.Funded by The National Lottery Heritage Fund, project partners, Scottish Power Renewables, the Scottish Government and local LEADER Programmes, the initiative is a key project under the Scottish Governmentrsquos  Challenge for Scottish Bioersity.

title: melrose-sevens-bosses-make-u-turn-road-closure
story: BOSSES at Melrose Rugby have made a U-turn on their plans to close off St Marys Road during next years sevens.As previously reported, the stretch was due to be shut for two weeks ndash to allow for a temporary stand to be erected.But following discussions with the towns community council, chiefs running the four-day tournament have changed their minds.Now St Marys road will only be partially closed on game days, with a traffic light system in place.Philip Morris, sevens tournament director at Melrose Rugby, said: ldquoAn event like this one will of course come with an element of disruption to the usual routine."The Melrose community has embraced the sevens every year, however, concerns around an expanded event are of course completely understandable."For the avoidance of doubt, wersquore working really hard to support local businesses as suppliers to the event."And wersquoll also be consulting with local residents to address any specic concerns they have too."We are confident the economic boost to Melrose and the surrounding Borders towns during the expanded sevens event will be huge."News of the U-turn has been welcomed by members of Melrose Community Council.Chairman William Windram said: "I still think the plans are a bit fluid at the moment, and I think there is still a lot of work going on behind the scenes."There are, however, still some issues like late night noise that have not been considered yet, but we have asked them [the club] to come back to our meeting in February to give us an update."Some amelioration has certainly taken place and we should be pleased."One of the concerns raised by Melrose Community Council at its November meeting was the impact the tournament would have on churchgoers ndash with the event taking place over the Easter weekend.In response, Mr Morris said: "We are working hard to ensure the important Easter Sunday church service is not impacted and people will be able to get to and from the church without signicant disruption."Now the traffic situation on St Marys Road is becoming clearer, we have a plan that we feel will satisfy our local residents. We look forward to sharing this plan with the local Minister and her congregation in the coming weeks."We would like to take this opportunity to thank the Melrose Community Council, local residents, and businesses for all their amazing support. We look forward to putting on a brilliant event in  and continuing to support the local and wider Borders community in the coming years."

title: borderline-funding-withdrawal-nothing-short-disgrace
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council and NHS Borders have been criticised for cutting funding to the Borderline mental health service.As we revealed last week the Galashiels-based service will be left without funding during .Since being set up in , Borderline has handled more than , calls, despite the phone lines only being open from pm till pm each night.However, NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council has withdrawn funding from the service, saying that other alternative options are available.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday Kelso councillor Euan Robson, who represented Roxburgh and Berwickshire at Holyrood between  and , asked the local authorityrsquos ruling executive: ldquoWho took the decision to terminate the funding for Borderline Helpline and for what reasons, and is any replacement service being set up Fellow Kelso councillor Tom Weatherston, who acts as the ruling executiversquos member for adult social care, replied: ldquoThe decision to stop funding Borderline was jointly taken by NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council, at the executive management team meeting.ldquoThe health and social care joint organisation, with signicant financial pressures in mind, reviewed its funding for this organisation.ldquoConsideration was given to a quality and impact assessment, and the external review of commissioned services, including Borderline.ldquoAlthough Borderline provides a good quality service, there are now alternative national helplines, such as Breathing Space and the Samaritans, as well as the local mental health and crisis team, and so we have reached the dficult decision to end the contract with six months notice.ldquoWersquod also like to highlight the other areas of prevention services in which we have invested, such as the local area coordination team, the Wellbeing College, and the wellbeing service.ldquoIn addition, we have also been working with primary care services to provide a comprehensive primary care mental health service, which is available directly to patients from GP practices across the Scottish Borders.ldquoWe will work hard with Borderline to find alternative sources of funding, and we are working hard with them to develop a transition plan.Councillor Robson asked a follow up question, telling the chamber: ldquoI appreciate that councillor Weatherston was not particularly involved in this decision, but would he agree with me that itrsquos nothing short of a disgrace that an organisation, partly staffed by volunteers, thatrsquos handled , calls from people in vulnerable situations for  years, and is open  days a year, has its funding withdrawn without prior consultation ldquoAnd worse still, it was allegedly informed that there is no right of appeal.Would he further accept that Borderline helping people in distress at a cost of pound, per annum actually saves resources where in the health and social care system, and this decision is therefore a  economy ldquoWill he further agree that some of the alternative provision mentioned does not fill the gap that Borderline occupies ldquoAnd finally, would he, or someone , therefore convene a meeting in the new year to find a way to save this service for the Borders community To which councillor Weatherston replied: ldquoI wonrsquot use the word disgrace, Irsquoll use the word disappointment."As the chief executive has said today, we face huge financial challenges.ldquoBorderline is a great service, but there is now a -hour, seven days a week service set up and funded by the NHS.ldquoNo one is in dispute that this is a great service, but we donrsquot have the funds to keep it going, unfortunately. Wersquove looked at other options, and the options available to people in the Borders now are really good.ldquoThis service is open for three hours a night, seven days a week. The alternative service is  , so there are other alternatives.ldquoWersquore working hard with the group to source other funding, but Irsquom sorry we have no other option.

title: odd-shaped-organiser-set-sights-peebles-high-fundraiser
story: ORGANISERS of the Odd Shaped Ball are to stage a new event in February in a bid to raise thousands of pounds to support Peebles High School following the recent fire.The PHS Recovery Ball will take place on Friday, February  at Peebles Hydro with tickets going on sale in early January.The event is being supported by local musicians, the Back Green Band, who have offered to perform free of charge, while the Hydrorsquos General Manager Patrick Diack has pledged his support as a venue partner.The Odd Shaped Ball has raised more than pound, since being launched in , generating funds for the junior sections of a number of local sports clubs, including football, rugby, golf, cricket, hockey, tennis and netball, as well as funding sports equipment for Priorsford, Kingsland and Halryude Primary Schools over the past two years.Their most recent event, staged in September, generated a record pound, on the night, with fantastic support from local parents and businesses.Co-organiser Mark Thomson told us: ldquoThe whole community has been affected by the fire at Peebles High School, but the pupils and teachers have shown great resilience in overcoming many of the challenges they are facing."The Odd Shaped Ball epitomes the community spirit in Peebles and we immediately thought doing something similar in the aftermath of the fire would be a great way of showing our support, bringing people together and raising valuable funds that are needed by the school in the months ahead.ldquoItrsquos also the weekend after Valentinersquos Day so wersquore recommending that couples ditch their plans for a romantic night and come along to have a great night at the PHS Recovery Ball instead!A table of  for the event will cost pound, which will include a special  Gin ndash distilled at Peebles Hydro ndash on arrival, three-course meal, live band and other entertainment.An array of fantastic prizes will be up for grabs in the raffle and auction, with the red-carpet photographer also hand to capture the best moments.Tickets will be available via the Odd Shaped Ball Facebook page and you can register your interest now. Every penny raised will go towards the Peebles High School fund to support the departments most affected by the fire.Co-organiser Ross Duncan added: "Wersquove already been contacted by a number of people and businesses across Scotland who have offered to support the event so we want to tap into that and quickly channel it in a positive way."We hope the local community will also get behind the Ball, through buying tickets, providing sponsorship or donating a prize.ldquoThe Odd Shaped Ball has been a hugely popular sell-out event for the past six years with  people attending so we hope we can replicate that success for this event."We appreciate there are many charity events that people are asked to get behind, but we believe helping young people at Peebles High School is a very worthy cause at this time.Further updates will be made available at www.facebook OddShapedBallPeebles

title: borderers-feature-queens-new-year-honours-list
story: SEVERAL Borderers have been included in the Queens New Year Honours List.Steve Penny from the Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue Team has been awarded an MBE.The -year-old from Lindean has been a volunteer with the rescue team since moving to the area in .He also joined the Search  Rescue Dog Association Scotlandas a handler in the same year.Steve said: "I was quite shocked when I got the letter, but also very proud."It means a lot as my grandfather got an MBE in , and at this time when my father has recently died it holds a very special meaning."As well as his local roles within mountain rescue, which have included Team Leader, Assistant Leader and Secretary, Steve is also the wellbeing officer for Scottish Mountain Rescue.In , his wellbeing framework for volunteer rescue responders was rolled out across Scotland and is now forming the backbone of a wider UK Wellbeing Initiative via UK Search and Rescue.And he is also a leading trainer across the country as part of the SMR Search Working Group.Steve has also taken on a series of Executive positions within Scottish Mountain Rescue over the years - as Secretary between  and  and as vice-chair from  to .Mr Penny added: "The team has changed over the years but we have always had a good team of people."Over the years weve attended many, many incidents."One that stands out for me was when I was with my dog during an avalanche, and although it was a fatality we were still able to locate the body quickly."Receiving an OBE for services to Animal Health is Tweeddales Dr Martyn Blissitt.The Scottish Government veterinary adviser has been at the forefront of the countrys fight against disease in farming livestock.After qualying as a veterinary surgeon in , Martyn completed a PhD at Edinburgh University seven years later.He spent his early working le in Somerset and Australia before joining the State Veterinary Service in Taunton during the BSE crisis of , moving to Ayr Animal Health Office the following year.He was promoted to Veterinary Adviser to SEERAD in  and has remained an adviser with the Scottish Government, being credited with Scotland achieving official TB free status.Berwickshires Ian Davidson has also been awarded an OBE for Services to Agriculture.Mr Davidson is Head of Agriculture Policy at the Scottish Government.He has most recently been responsible for the Scottish Rural Development Programme.And has previously held posts in developing the current CAP in Scotland and also in the Area Office network as part of the RPID.

title: ryan-jenn-set-open-string-jams-23rd-year
story: THE String Jam Club opens its rd year next week with the highly-acclaimed Scottish trad duo of Ryan Young and Jenn Butterworth.Ryan leads the New Wave of traditional Scottish fiddlers, according to the BBC, bringing new and exciting ideas to the folk genre.He holds both a first class honours and a Masters degree from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, as well as being a twice a finalist in both the BBC Radio  Young Folk Awards and the BBC Scotland Young Traditional Musician of the Year.He was nominated for the Horizon Award at the  BBC Radio  Folk Awards and was the winner of Folking Best Musician for .Despite his comparatively young years, Ryan is already on his way to becoming a folk giant.And while his CV is fairly impressive, the superb guitarist who will be accompanying him at the County Hotel has just as extraordinary a background.Jenn Butterworth was Musician of the Year at the MG Alba Scots Trad Music Awards , and is one of only four musicians shortlisted for Musician of the Year Award at the prestigious BBC Radio  Folk Awards .Based in Glasgow, she is a lynchpin of the vibrant and thriving Scottish folk scene, performing regularly with a wide range of artists including her own projects, Jenn Butterworth  Laura-Beth Salter, and the fabulous Kinnaris Quintet.Jenn is a highly recognised teacher with a wide range of experience, and was recently awarded Tutor of the Year at the  Scots Trad Music Awards.She is lecturer in Practical Studies in the Traditional Music Department of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, and a regular member of the teaching staff for Glasgow Fiddle Workshop.Ryan and Jenn were nominated as Folk Band of the Year in the Scots Trad Music Awards, and were the only UK artists to be selected to perform at the Womex Expo .String Jam promoter Allie Fox said: "They gave a simply awe-inspiring performance at String Jam Club last year and are back by popular demand."The music was exhilarating, magical, and exciting, nearly causing a riot after the first set of tunes."They got two standing ovations and three encores, and the atmosphere was so exciting that we just had to book them again. This will be an inspirational gig and an unbelievable display of exceptional trad musicianship."Tickets for Ryan Young and Jenn Butterworth at the String Jam Club on Saturday, January , priced at pound, are available online from Eventbrite, in person from the County Hotel or by phone -.Doors open at .pm for an pm start.

title: ross-tunes-hawick-music-club
story: HAWICK Music Club welcomeclassical guitarist Ross Wilson for their opening concert of .On Sunday, January , the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland graduate will perform at the Cornucopia Room.In  Ross began studying part-time at the Segovia Guitar Academy in Pordenone, Italy with Professor Paola Pegoraro, after graduating with a Masters in Scotland.Modern Spanish composers feature mostly in Rossrsquo repertoire, beginning with Frederico Mompou and his elegant Catalanonian folk inspired music.Ross has a particular interest in Baroque and early music which is reflected in his choice of composers, such as JS Bach and John Downland.He has given recitals across Britain including at the Glasgow City Halls as part of the BBC SSO Club Concert series.Ross will present a warm Mediterranean programme during his visit to Hawick on January .Tickets, priced at pound per adult with under s free, are available from Muriel Wilson on  The concert starts at .pm.

title: lamont-rolls-red-carpet-westminster-visits
story: FRESHLY re-elected MP, John Lamont, has urged locals and schools to get in touch with himthey would like to visit Westminster in .MR Lamont has welcomed hundreds of constituents and a number of schools to Westminster since he became and MP in .Borders schools making educational visits to Parliament can claim  percent of receipted travel costs, up to a maximum of pound.MPs can also secure tickets for Prime Ministerrsquos Questions and other debates and tours free of charge for constituents visiting the Parliament.The MP Berwickshire, Roxburgh  Selkirk said: ldquoI always enjoy welcoming constituents and students to Westminster.ldquoMost people only ever see the palace on their televisions or in the newspaper."However, the building has some fantastic rooms to see as well as being steeped in history.ldquoI always get great feedback from visitors saying how informative and friendly the parliamentary staff have been during their visit."Teachers also think that visiting Parliament gives their pupils a better understanding of how our political system worksldquoI would urge anyone to get in touch with me directlythey fancy seeing Westminster as part of their trip to London.Anyone interested in visiting Parliament can contact Johnrsquos office or email him at john.lamont.mp@parliament.uk.

title: newtown-set-new-enlarged-playpark
story: CHILDREN in Newtown St Boswells will have plenty to cheer about later this year as the village has moved up the playpark pecking order.Because of delays to the new Earlston Primary School development, there is outstanding cash earmarked for new play facilities.And it has now been announced that Newtown will get the new facilities later in .Scottish Borders Council convenor David Parker explained: ldquoOne of the parks which was agreed for the new financial year was Earlston, but this project cannot proceed until the new school is developed and therefore the funding resources against the project have been released.ldquoOnce we have the outcome of the tender process in Newtown, I will be able to confirm more information about timescale in terms of getting a design which we can take to the community for consultation.ldquo Around pound, will be spent on developing the playpark at Sprouston Road.As well as replacing the current swings and slides, the new enlarged park will feature more equipment to suit a wider age range of children.The move has been welcomed by local councillor Elaine Thornton-Nicol. She said: ldquoThe need for a new and extended playpark was identied a number of years ago.ldquoI want to say a huge thank you to David Parker and all the officers that have been involved in making this a very Merry Christmas for Newtown St Boswells.ldquoWe are looking forward to seeing the designs in  and working with the community to make this pound, do as much as it can for our village.Discussions have already taken place between Councillors Parker and Thornton-Nicol, as well as community council secretary Fiona MacPherson, about the need for a better and larger park to meet the needs of the villagersquos growing population.Ms MacPherson told us: ldquoEveryone will be thrilled that we are on our way to a fabulous play facility.

title: hamilton-calls-government-help-save-borders-high-streets
story: BORDERS MSP Rachael Hamilton has called on the Scottish Government to do more to tackle the decline of the high street and encourage increased local footfall in town centres.Figures show that footfall in most Borders towns has fallen signicantly over the past decade.Towns such as Galashiels and Hawick have been hit hard with shoppers either going online or to the cities.Mrs Hamilton wants the Scottish Government to help by addressing crippling business rates which has left many shops vacant.The member for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire said: "Tackling the decline of our high streets is a constant uphill battle, but with the right package of measures in place, we can reverse the trend.ldquoBusinesses wonrsquot move to an areathere isnrsquot an incentive to do so."We need to create a pro-business atmosphere on our high streets, with emphasis on local start-ups.ldquoBusiness rates relief and the alleviation of planning restrictions would ensure that there are far fewer barriers to business moving in."As well as cutting business rates, Mrs Hamilton wants a plan to support the regions high streets become dynamic, flexible, welcoming spaces, able to provide a range of dferent experiences.She believes effective BIDs are also beneficial.Mrs Hamilton added: "We need to see more incentives for local businesses to move in, expand and fill vacant premises on the high street.ldquoIn the new year, I will be continuing my work to save our high streets, and will liaise proactively with all high street businesses to forward my plans for a better high street."

title: teaching-resume-peebles-high-school-february
story: STUDENTS from Peebles High School willto the school in February after extensive works on the site were undertaken during the Christmas holiday.Since the blaze at the High School on November , students were ided between classrooms and community centres in Peebles and Galashiels for face-to-face teaching.S-S students willto Peebles High on Monday, February  after their prelim exams which finish on January .S-S students will complete school work from home on February  so staff can ensure a safe and organisedto the site. Learning materials will be provided through the Show my Homework app and Glow. Junior students will thento the High School on February .Tracey Logan, Chief Executive of Scottish Borders Council, said: ldquoWe have continued to work right up to Christmas and in the days since to put plans in place to have all pupils back at Peebles High School as soon as possible. This includes the provision of temporary classrooms in the High Schoolrsquos grounds and preparations for these are well underway.ldquoAlthough work continues, we are now fairly confident that, all going well, all pupils will be able toto Peebles High School over the two days of rd and th February. This still depends on a number of factors but with the help and support of a huge range of staff and partners, we are very optimistic that we can achieve this.ldquoWe would like to give parents and carers as much notice as possible this includes the decision to ask S-S pupils to work from home on Monday  February. The logistics of moving from the temporary sites and preparing the new arrangements are hugely challenging and the safety and well-being of pupils is our priority. As such, the operation to move from the temporary sites from Friday lunchtime over the weekend and into Monday needs to be carefully planned and managed.ldquoI am delighted that we are in such a positive position so quickly given the scale of the challenge. We will continue to work on the details around these plans and will keep pupils, parents and staff updated as we make more progress.Parts of the school which were greatly damaged after the fire will still be inaccessible to students for their safety.Teaching and travel arrangements which were in place prior to the Christmas break will remain when studentsto teaching on Monday, January .All the temporary teaching locations used by Peebles High will be given back to Live Borders on January , with the exception of the Drill Hall which will continue to be used as a back-up teaching venue.Ms Logan added: ldquoOnce again Irsquod like to pay tribute to everyone who has supported the Council and Peebles High School during this extremely challenging period, and of course to all the pupils, parents and staff for their patience during this time.ldquoThe support of our partners Live Borders and CGI, numerous contractors and the local community has been invaluable.ldquoIrsquod also like to publicly thank all my staff who have worked so hard since  November to get us to this position.Leader of Scottish Borders Council, councillor Shona Haslam said: ldquoI would like to again thank the officers, staff and pupils for their work in getting us to this stage."To have all the pupils back on one site only weeks after the devastating fire is an amazing achievement."We will continue to work on a longer term solution with partners to ensure that we continue to provide the best quality education to our young people."The past couple of weeks have shown what an amazing community we have in Peeblesshire, and through this resilience, perseverance and hard work we can all be very hopeful for the future of our school.Updates for Peebles High School can be found at www.scotborders.gov.uk phsfire

title: minister-champions-borders-distress-service
story: A SUPPORT team in the Borders have been commended by the countrys Minister for Mental Health.Clare Haughey MSP met with Borders DBI representatives in Galashiels last week to commend them in helping the national project win a prestigious Scottish Health Award.DBI provides an lsquoask once - get help fastrsquo early intervention for people in distress or emotional pain who do not need emergency medical treatment.After an inidualrsquos immediate distress is tackled, the person is askedthey would like further support andthey agree, they are referred to the DBI service with a promise of contact within the next  hours.Ms Haughey said: ldquoI want to congratulate the whole team on the fantastic work they do to support people who are experiencing signicant challenges in their lives.ldquoThis work supports our broad vision on mental health, of a Scotland where people can get the right help at the right time, expect recovery and fully enjoy their rights, free from discrimination and stigma.Data gathered so far shows on average, the level of distress of those who have received DBI support, has halved.Welcoming the minister to The Hive last week was Borders DBI programme manager Haylis Smith.She said: ldquoAlmost  people in the Borders have been supported to manage their distress since the pilot began.ldquoThe support given to these iniduals is the real reward for all of us, but we were delighted the Minister recognised the efforts of the arearsquos hospital emergency department, Police Scotland, Scottish Ambulance Service, primary care and third sector staff.The Scottish Government funded pilot picked up the Care for Mental Health award at the Scottish Health Awards in November.DBI programme manager Kevin OrsquoNeill, said: ldquoWe were delighted the Minister paid a visit to the Borders DBI team to hear and see for herself how their efforts are making a real dference to peoplersquos lives day in and day out.ldquoIt is the sensitivity of our staff to those in distress that inspires us all to work together to improve the outcomes and experiences of these people when they need help most.

title: celebrating-five-years-weight-loss-borders
story: FOR five years diet consultants Mark and Nicola Lafferty have been helping people in the Borders transform their lives and waistlines.This month, the couple scooped a long service recognition award in running their successful : diet consultancyrsquos, formerly known as the Cambridge Weight Plan, in Peebles and Galashiels.With Markrsquos training as an addictions therapist and Nicolarsquos mental health support background, the duo combined their skills, and pride themselves in taking an empathic approach in helping their clients achieve their goals.ldquoWe realise everyone is dferent and sometimes losing weight isnrsquot as straightforward as going on a diet, said Mark.ldquoWe help clients by looking into the reasons they gained weight in the first place and help them work on changing their mind-set to work more effectively, not only at losing the excess weight but in keeping it off too.They say the proof is in the pudding, which is true for the Laffertys who used their own dramatic weight loss with the diet to inspire others.Mark told us: ldquoI struggled with weight issues."As an addictions a counsellor I could help people with alcohol and drug dependency but I story: A crowdfunding appeal to raise money for legal support for a British teenager found guilty of lying about being gang-raped has passed pound,.The ldquohelp teen victim get justice in Cyprus GoFundMe page was set up by British lawyer John Hobbs in August to raise cash for the -year-oldrsquos legal representation.The teenager said she was raped by up to  Israeli tourists in a hotel room in the party town of Ayia Napa on July .----But she was charged and the dozen young men, aged between  and , who were arrested over the incident, were freed after she signed a retraction statement  days later.The woman, who had been due to go to university in September, claimed in court she was raped but forced to change her account under pressure from Cypriot police.The GoFundMe page has continued to receive thousands of pounds in donationsafter the woman was found guilty on Monday, and had hit its pound, target on Tuesday night.The Foreign Office said the UK was ldquoseriously concerned about the fairness of the womanrsquos trial and it is understood officials have raised the ldquodeeply distressing case with the Cypriot authorities.Lawyers and campaigners criticised the justice system after she was convicted of public mischief at Famagusta District Court, in Paralimni, on Monday.And the psychologist who assessed the woman as part of her defence case, Dr Christine Tizzard, said she was concerned the trial had not fully considered that she had been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder .She told the : ldquoThe salient point is that she was diagnosed with PTSD. Thatrsquos a standalone diagnosis. Itrsquos a valid diagnosis and it hasnrsquot really been fully represented.ldquoAside the fact it hasnrsquot been fully represented, it means shersquos been unable to get the treatment she so sorely needs and every day shersquos not having treatment the worse it gets.But the government of Cyprus has said it has ldquofull confidence in the justice system and the courts.Cyprusrsquo attorney general said on Tuesday that he could not suspend the trial because she had levelled ldquograve accusations against police investigators that had to be adjudicated in court.He said the womanrsquos allegation in a video found on some of the Israelisrsquo mobile phones.ldquoThe defendant gave police a  rape claim, while having full knowledge that this was a lie, he said.ldquoThere was no rape, or violence,
